chargeHist.descr: Homicide by Intox Use of Vehicle (2nd+)

result.execSummary:
The defendant Channing Hunter Mathews was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case. One or more other charges in this case were dismissed. The dismissed charges were not proven and have no legal effect. Channing Hunter Mathews is presumed innocent of the dismissed charges.

  • Channing Hunter Mathews was found guilty of Homicide by Negligent Operation/Vehicle, a class G felony, Wisconsin Statutes 940.10(1).
  • Channing Hunter Mathews was found guilty of OWI (2nd), an unclassified misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(a).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

superMiscConds.notes: State given 60 days to submit restitution request and defense has 30 days to agree with amount or request a hearing.

Comply with all recommendations from alcohol assessment.

No consumption or possession of alcoholic beverages; no entering bars, taverns or liquor stores.  Agent can approve being in bars, taverns or liquor stores if agent approves of employment.

No consumption or possession of any controlled substances except those legally prescribed to defendant and take prescribed medications exactly as directed to be taken.

Attend, participate in and successfully complete any other assessments, counseling or treatment deemed appropriate by Department of Corrections.

Participate in victim offender mediation if requested by victim's family.

Pay supervision fees as determined by the Department of Corrections.
Obtain and maintain full time employment that is acceptable and approved by agent.
